title: How to Measure Static Pressure with a Manometer

steps.title: Plug your pressure probes into the digital manometer and turn it on.
steps.content: Plug your pressure probes into the digital manometer and turn it on. Generally, a manometer will have 2 inputs for pressure probes: channel A and channel B. Pressure hoses look like long, rubber tubes, and the probes look like small metal hooks. Attach your pressure hoses to each input point and then attach the static pressure probes to each hose. If your manometer has a magnet on the back, place it on the furnace for easy access. Press the power button to turn the manometer on. [1] X Research source You can purchase a digital manometer at most hardware stores for under $40. The probes and hoses come with the manometer when you purchase it. For large or industrial furnaces, you can use up to 4 probes. For residential furnaces, use only 2 probes.

steps.title: Insert the channel A probe into the gas or electric furnace before the fan.
steps.content: Insert the channel A probe into the gas or electric furnace before the fan. Slide your first probe into the hole on the furnace that is situated before the fan. This hole is on the front of the furnace and may be situated near the filter. Point the very end of your probe downward toward the airflow of the fan. [2] X Trustworthy Source Energy Star Program run by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and Department of Energy focused on educating consumers about energy efficiency Go to source If you are unclear on where the parts of your furnace are, consult your userâ€™s manual.

steps.title: Put your channel B probe into the furnace after the fan.
steps.content: Put your channel B probe into the furnace after the fan. Slide your channel B probe into the furnace after the flow of air through the fan. Point the end of the probe downward toward the airflow of the furnace. [3] X Research source If there is not a hole in the furnace after the fan, use a drill and a stepped-up drill bit to make a small hole near the coil of the furnace. This will be situated on the middle section of the furnace near the filter. Do not drill near or on top of the heat exchanger, or you could damage it. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Add the 2 numbers from your manometer together.
steps.content: Add the 2 numbers from your manometer together. Check your manometer to see what it is displaying. If one of the numbers is negative, treat it like a positive when you add your numbers together. Add the numbers on the manometer display to get a reading for your total external static pressure, or TESP, in inches of water column. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Address your static pressure if it is above 0.5 inches (1.3 cm).
steps.content: Address your static pressure if it is above 0.5 inches (1.3 cm). If the numbers from your manometer add up to less than 0.5 inches (1.3 cm), your TESP is healthy. If they add up to more than 0.5 inches (1.3 cm), your TESP is using too much air flow and should be addressed. [6] X Research source High static pressure can be caused by multiple things. Consult a professional HVAC technician to determine what can be done to fix your high static pressure.

steps.title: Insert your probes around the filter to test the area for pressure.
steps.content: Insert your probes around the filter to test the area for pressure. The most common cause of extra TESP is a dirty or incorrectly situated filter. Place your channel A probe above your filter and your channel B probe below your filter in the test port that is already there. Check the channel B probe on your manometer to see what it is reading. [7] X Trustworthy Source Energy Star Program run by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and Department of Energy focused on educating consumers about energy efficiency Go to source

steps.title: Change the filter if your filter pressure is higher than 0.1 inches (0.25 cm).
steps.content: Change the filter if your filter pressure is higher than 0.1 inches (0.25 cm). Change the filter and then test it again to see if your total external static pressure went down. If it did not lower after you changed the filter, consult a professional HVAC technician to see what is causing your high filter pressure. [8] X Trustworthy Source Energy Star Program run by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and Department of Energy focused on educating consumers about energy efficiency Go to source You can purchase furnace filters from the manufacturer of your specific furnace, or at most hardware stores.

steps.title: Test the evaporating coil pressure to examine the coil pressure drop.
steps.content: Test the evaporating coil pressure to examine the coil pressure drop. Insert your channel A probe into the test port on top of the coil. Insert the channel B probe after the coil. In most furnaces, this is in the test port near the fan. Add up the numbers that your manometer is displaying. [9] X Research source The coil in your furnace acts as a heat exchanger. If it is working too hard, it can damage your furnace.

steps.title: Consult an HVAC technician if your coil pressure is above 1.4 inches (3.6 cm).
steps.content: Consult an HVAC technician if your coil pressure is above 1.4 inches (3.6 cm). If your coil pressure is right around 1.4 inches (3.6 cm), it is healthy. If it is significantly above that number, your furnace coil is working too hard and the pressure should be addressed.
